PAIMIO

DESIGN · JAVASCRIPT · SCSS

View the finished site

View the repository on GitHub

This is a simple static site I was commissioned to create as a part of an art installation at the Paimio Sanatorium in Finland, a beautiful building designed by the Finnish architect, designer, and artist Alvar Aalto. I was given various poems, images, and related works to the installation and I created an experience I think of as a living poem.

IDEATION

Preliminary sketches for the Paimio site along with notes on the interaction.

For a while before this I had the idea of playing with the concept of pop-ups. One iteration of my design for my personal portfolio allowed the user to drag around and jumble up the images on the front page of my site. I determined that it didn’t make sense for that specific project, but when I was approached for this project I was immediately inspired to explore this idea further.

DESIGN

The design choice to intersperse the poems and text fragments among the images and other files creates a sense of exploration, and the fact that the divs that pop up when a list item is clicked on are scattered about the page, sometimes overlapping, adds to that experience. It’s akin to a cluttered desktop, and the soothing, shifting colors of the background balance the unorganized nature of the pop-ups. My favorite part of this project is playing with the list as a way of organizing information while abstracting by involving the user in the ordering of the information by dragging the pop-ups around on the page.

One thing that would have been cool to add is the ability to join div elements when you drag them together, like fitting puzzle pieces together. I thought that this would be too complex and detract from the simplicity of the design so I’ll probably incorporate it into a later project.

DEVELOPMENT

I could have used jQuery’s UI library to allow users to click and drag divs, but I found a much shorter code snippet on Stack Overflow and I implemented it instead. The part I am most proud of on this site, besides using .column-count() for the main ul is the jQuery used to open and close the pop-up divs. 

$(function() {

	var z = 10; // variable for z-index

	// Show popups when you click an li
	$('a').click(function(e) {
		var windowHeight = $(window).height();
		var windowWidth = $(window).width();
		var classname = $(this).attr('class');
		$('.popup.' + classname).show().css({
			'opacity' : 1,
			'z-index' : z,
			'left' : randomNumber(1, (windowWidth - 300)) + 'px',
			'top' : randomNumber(1, (windowHeight - 700)) + 'px'
		}).addClass('showing');
		z += 1;

		…

		// hide div when class matches x link class
		$('.x').click(function() {
		var classname = $(this).attr('class').split(' ')[1];
		$('.popup.' + classname).removeClass('showing').hide();
		$.each($('audio'), function () {
			this.pause();
		});
	});

	// close all 
	$('#closeAll').click(function() {
		$('.showing').removeClass('showing').hide();
		$('#closeAll').hide();
	});

	…

});

This was one of my favorite projects I've had the opportunity to work on for the challenge to make an intriguing user experience while keeping the design simple and fun. I loved getting to experiment with fun CSS gradient animations and figuring out how to get the pop-ups to work, and I'm super proud of the outcome.

THANKS FOR WATCHING!
